header.title: SEPHER HA-RAZIM: The Book of the Mysteries

central_thesis: The book, a reconstructed Jewish magical handbook from the early Talmudic period (late 3rd/early 4th CE), presents a collection of practical magical praxeis embedded within an elaborate seven-firmament cosmological framework. The translator suggests that the diverse magical formulas likely originated from an older folk tradition and were later contextualized and legitimized by editors within a more 'traditional' Jewish celestial hierarchy, demonstrating the syncretistic nature of Hellenistic Jewish popular religion.

structure_content.summary: Outlines the mission of the Society of Biblical Literature's Texts and Translations project, particularly the Pseudepigrapha Series, to make ancient, often inaccessible, texts available with reliable English translations for scholars of 'biblical literature'.

Michael A. Morgan expresses gratitude for research support and acknowledges contributors who assisted in the translation and understanding of the text, emphasizing the detailed review by Morton Smith.

Describes Mordecai Margalioth's discovery of Genizah fragments in 1963, leading to his reconstruction and 1966 publication of 'Sepher Ha-Razim' (SHR). It places SHR in the early Talmudic period (late 3rd/early 4th CE), highlighting its value for understanding ancient Jewish magic. The introduction discusses the challenges of dating an eclectic text, pointing to Roman indictions (297 CE or 312 CE) as a terminus a quo, Hebrew language style, Greek technical terms, parallels to Greek Magical Papyri (PGM) and Aramaic incantation bowls, and cosmological similarities to Enoch and Hekhaloth literature. It argues that the magical praxeis likely predate the cosmological framework, representing a popular folk tradition, and notes the translation methodology.

Provides a list of Hebrew letter designations corresponding to the seven major codices and various Genizah fragments used by Margalioth in reconstructing the text, alongside symbols for other ancient and medieval sources, detailing their manuscript numbers and page references.

Introduces the 'Book of the Mysteries' as a divinely revealed text, given by the angel Raziel to Noah, and subsequently transmitted through a lineage to King Solomon. It describes the book's purpose: to impart knowledge of celestial mechanics, astrological signs, lunar and solar observations, names and authority of angelic overseers for each of the seven firmaments, and how to harness their power for various magical operations and understanding of earthly events.

Introduces 'Shamayim' with seven encampments overseen by angels (WRPNY'L, TYGRH, DNHL, KLMYY', SYMWR, PSKR, BW'L). It outlines praxeis for healing (WRPNY'L's angels), causing destruction or exile (TYGRH's angels, using water, glass vial, pottery, incantations), predicting future events or yearly conditions (DNHL's angels, using hieratic papyrus, oil), gaining favor or inspiring love (KLMYY's angels, using lion heart, blood, wine, gold foil), communicating with celestial bodies, ghosts, and spirits (SYMWR's angels, using cock sacrifice, cakes, flask, myrtle), catching fugitives (PSKR's angels, using copper lamellae), and interpreting dreams or foretelling future events (BW'L's angels, with specific preparations like wearing new cloak, abstinence, burning incense facing water).

Describes the 'heaven of heavens' containing frost, fog, snow, hail, and spirits of dread. It details twelve steps, each with specific angelic entities requiring stringent purity rituals (abstinence from certain foods, wine, contact with impurity, women in menstruation) for invocation. Praxeis include silencing enemies (first step angels, using idol's ashes), invoking love or favorable planetary conjunctions (second step angels, using lamellae, ritual bath), nullifying intentions (third step angels, using lamellae), causing insomnia or torment (fourth step angels, using a dog's head and lead lamella), igniting or extinguishing fire (fifth step angels, using sulphur; sixth step angels, using spikenard oil, honey, and sun exposure), and expelling wild animals or binding rivers (seventh step angels, using bronze or stone images and lamellae).

Filled with storerooms of mist, thunder, and lightning, ruled by three princes (YBNY'L, RHTY'L, DLQY'L) associated with fire. Practical operations include extinguishing bathhouse fires (YBNY'L, using salamander and oil) and kindling fires (RHTY'L, using oil), as well as aiding in horse races (DLQY'L, using silver lamellae inscribed with horse and angel names).

Features angels of fire and cold, a bridal chamber of the sun, and overseers who lead the sun by day and night. Praxeis focus on divination and viewing celestial entities: observing the sun during the day (requiring seven days of purity, incense, and invocation) and seeing the sun at night to ask questions (requiring three weeks of purity, white garments, and an invocation of Holy Helios facing north).

Governed by twelve princes of glory, each representing a month. Operations aim to predict future events, such as personal fate or monthly occurrences like rain, famine, or war. This involves using refined gold lamellae, inscribed with angelic names and months, placed in aged oil and subjected to an adjuration for seven nights under the stars, with strict adherence to purity rituals.

Contains spirits of the righteous and is overseen by two officers, 'PRKSY (west) and TWQPYRS (east), who command armies of angels. Practical applications include gaining protection during journeys or war, achieving invisibility, and binding or releasing spirits. This is achieved by creating an iron ring with a pure gold lamella, engraving angelic names and a man/lion image, worn on the finger or placed in the mouth during invocation.

Described as a realm of sevenfold light, containing the throne of glory, supported by Hayot and Opanim. This section primarily serves as a doxology, praising the boundless power and majesty of God. While specific praxeis for this firmament are not explicitly detailed here, its angelic entities are invoked in the First Firmament for dream interpretation, highlighting its ultimate divine authority and connection to revealing hidden knowledge.

Presents the Hebrew lists of angelic names for each encampment within the seven firmaments. These lists are provided without speculative vocalization, intended for practitioners seeking to engage directly with the textual source for their magical operations.

Comprises comprehensive indices, categorizing ancient sources (Scripture and Magical Literature like PGM), non-angelic proper names (e.g., Abraham, Adam, Helios), principal angelic names (e.g., WRPNY'L, TYGRH), properties of angels (e.g., fire, wings, sound), purposes for which angels can be made to serve (e.g., healing, love, protection), and magical materials (e.g., lamellae, myrrh, animal parts), facilitating research and practical application.

key_concepts.definition: A reconstructed Jewish magical handbook, dated to the early Talmudic period (late 3rd/early 4th CE), which combines a cosmological framework with practical magical spells and rituals. It is significant for understanding the syncretistic nature of Jewish folk magic during the Hellenistic age.

A seven-firmament structure detailing angelic hierarchies, their domains, and functions. This framework, reflecting similarities to Enoch and Hekhaloth literature, appears to serve as a legitimizing narrative for the magical praxeis contained within the text, presenting them as divinely sanctioned practices.

Practical spells, rituals, and incantations intended for a wide range of purposes, from healing and protection to divination and curses. These praxeis often involve specific material preparations, precise timing, and invocations of angelic beings, showing strong parallels with Greek Magical Papyri (PGM) and Aramaic incantation bowls.

Specific high-ranking angelic entities assigned to each firmament or its subdivisions. These overseers command numerous subordinate angels and are the primary points of invocation for practitioners seeking to engage the magical system for various operations.

A fundamental requirement for all magical operations within SHR. It involves strict adherence to ritual cleanliness, including periods of abstinence from specific foods (e.g., blood-yielding animals, palm fruit), wine, sexual contact (especially with menstruating women), and impurities, reflecting a blend of traditional Jewish ritual concerns with magical practice.

Thin metal plates, typically made of copper, silver, or gold, inscribed with angelic names, sigils, or formulas. These objects serve as a primary medium for encoding spells, worn for protection, or buried at specific locations to enact magical effects.

A Roman system of tax cycles, used as a historical marker (terminus a quo, starting 297 CE or 312 CE depending on the dating context) to help date the compilation or a particular redaction of the SHR text, indicating a period of Roman influence on the document.

A text compiled from various and disparate sources. SHR is considered eclectic due to its blend of Jewish, Greek, and possibly Egyptian magical elements and cosmological ideas, reflecting the broader syncretism prevalent in the Hellenistic world.

practical_system.description: The operative magical system of Sepher Ha-Razim functions by invoking and directing specific angelic entities residing within a seven-tiered celestial hierarchy (firmaments). The practitioner, through rigorous ritual purity, precise material preparations, and spoken adjurations (incantations), aims to compel these angels to perform desired tasks. Each firmament and its angelic overseers are associated with particular domains and magical effects, allowing for a diverse range of praxeis. The efficacy of the magic is deeply tied to the practitioner's state of purity and the accurate execution of complex ritual instructions.
tools: Lamellae: Copper, silver, or gold plates for inscriptions and amulets.
Hieratic Papyrus: For writing spells, predictions, and angelic names.
Vessels: Glass vials, flasks, cups, and unfired pottery vessels for ritual liquids.
Incense and Spices: Myrrh, frankincense, istorgon, musk, and other chosen spices.
Animal Products: Lion cub heart and blood, fat from a black ox's brain, white cock for sacrifice, head of a black dog.
Natural Elements: Water from seven springs, sea/river water, ashes (from idol's bread offering), bay leaves, sulphur, myrtle wood/twig.
Rings: Iron rings and silver rings (sometimes with hollow compartments) for engraving and wearing.
Images: Bronze or stone figures of animals or men for binding/expelling entities.
rituals: Ritual Purity (Taharah): Strict abstinence from impure foods (e.g., blood-yielding animals, fish, palm fruit), wine, contact with the dead, and sexual activity (especially with menstruating women) for specified durations (e.g., three weeks, seven days).

Angelic Invocations/Adjurations: Recitation of specific angelic names (individual angels, overseers, or groups) a precise number of times (e.g., 7, 21, 300), often while facing cardinal directions or celestial bodies.

Sacrifice and Offerings: Slaughtering animals (e.g., lion cub, white cock) for blood collection, burning incense, spices, myrrh, and frankincense on coals, and pouring libations of oil, honey, wine, blood, or water.

Magical Object Creation: Inscribing names, symbols, or formulas onto lamellae (metal plates of copper, silver, or gold) for use as amulets, or onto hieratic papyrus slips. Forming images (bronze or stone) of animals or men.

Ritual Placement and Manipulation: Burying inscribed objects in specific locations (e.g., under a doorstep, in a wall, at city entrance), placing consecrated materials in particular vessels, breaking pottery, or directing ritual waters.

Celestial Timing: Performing operations at specific times of day or night (e.g., first/second hour of night, third hour), phases of the moon (e.g., full moon, waning), or solar events (e.g., rising sun), and days of the month (e.g., seventh, twentieth, twenty-ninth).

relevant_quotes.text: In the current volume the series presents only an English translation of an ancient text. This divergence from the usual practice is due to the fact that the Hebrew text of the Sepher Ha-Razim is readily available in a recent edition, while no English translation exists. It is hoped that the current volume will make more widely known this important work of Jewish magical literature.
Dating an eclectic text is difficult at best. The consensus of those scholars who have worked with the text is to support Margalioth's dating of SHR to the early fourth or late third century CE.

It seems to me more likely that the magical praxeis have been provided with a cosmological framework intended to make them appear as legitimate Jewish practices. Thus the formulas, spells, and incantations presumably existed prior to their present form.

Magic was the common property of the people of the Greco-Roman world. The praxeis could have arisen in any part of that world and have been initially preserved in any part of that world. To attempt to locate a single place of origin would be futile.
SHR is a fine example of the syncretistic nature of the Hellenistic world.

I adjure you angels of wrath and destruction, that you will rise up against the ship of N son of N and that you not permit it to sail from any place. But if wind (sufficient) for sailing come to it, then let (the wind) carry it out to sea and shake it (so it sinks) in the midst of the sea and let neither man nor cargo be saved from it.

Holy Helios who rises in the east, good mariner, trustworthy leader of the sun's rays, reliable (witness), who of old didst establish the mighty wheel (of the heavens), holy orderer, ruler of the axis (of the heaven). Lord, Brilliant Leader, King, Soldier. I, N son of N, present my supplication before you, that you will appear to me without (causing me) fear, and you will be revealed to me without causing me terror, and you will conceal nothing from me and will tell me truthfully all that I desire.

critical_analysis.relevance: Sepher Ha-Razim is a foundational text for the study of Jewish magic and Western Esotericism. It provides unparalleled insights into the operative magical practices and cosmological beliefs of Jewish communities in the early Talmudic and Hellenistic periods. The text's syncretistic nature, blending Jewish monotheistic themes with Greek, Egyptian, and possibly other regional magical traditions (as evidenced by parallels with PGM and Aramaic incantation bowls), makes it invaluable for understanding the cultural and religious interchange of the era. It challenges conventional understandings of 'orthodoxy' by showcasing the popular religious practices and folk traditions that existed alongside developing rabbinic Judaism, highlighting the diverse expressions of piety and engagement with the divine.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic scholars and students of Jewish studies, ancient history, Hellenistic religion, biblical literature, and Western Esotericism. Additionally, practitioners of ceremonial magic, Qabalah, and grimoire traditions interested in historical magical systems and their practical application would find this annotated translation a valuable resource for research and operative work.
